q: What are the symptoms of a broken collarbone?
a: Symptoms of a broken collarbone include severe pain, swelling or bruising, change in shape, and bone sticking out of the skin. In rare cases, it can lead to complications such as chest pain, difficulty breathing, or coughing up blood.

q: When should I seek medical advice for a possible broken collarbone?
a: You should seek medical advice as soon as possible if you think you have a broken collarbone.

q: What should I do if I suspect I have a broken collarbone while waiting to see a doctor?
a: While waiting to see a doctor, you can use a towel or bandage to put the affected arm in a sling, apply pressure to any bleeding, avoid using the affected shoulder or arm, and avoid touching the bone if it's sticking out from your skin.

q: How is a broken collarbone treated?
a: A broken collarbone is usually treated by putting the arm in a sling to help it heal. Painkillers may be prescribed. Surgery is rare but may be necessary for severe breaks. After leaving the hospital, follow-up appointments will be needed to monitor the healing process.

q: How long does it usually take to recover from a broken collarbone?
a: Most people recover from a broken collarbone in 6 to 8 weeks. Children tend to recover quicker, usually in 3 to 4 weeks. Wearing a sling for 2 to 3 weeks and resting the shoulder is necessary for a few more weeks.

q: What can I do to aid in the recovery from a broken collarbone?
a: You can take painkillers regularly, do the shoulder and arm exercises given to you, try to do your usual daily activities without using your shoulder, and consult your doctor for advice on when you can return to more physical activities.

q: What are the urgent signs that require immediate medical attention?
a: Urgent signs that require immediate medical attention include a changed shape of the shoulder, sudden swelling, bone sticking out from the skin, heavy bleeding, difficulty breathing, chest pain, or coughing up blood. In such cases, it is advised to call 999 or go to the nearest A&E.

q: Where can I find information on how to make an arm sling?
a: You can find information on how to make an arm sling on the St John Ambulance website.

q: What are the potential complications of a broken collarbone?
a: Potential complications of a broken collarbone are rare but can include chest pain, difficulty breathing, or coughing up blood. It is important to seek medical advice if any of these symptoms occur.

q: When should I go to A&E for a possible broken collarbone?
a: You should go to A&E if your shoulder has changed shape, swollen quickly, or if there is bone sticking out from the skin. Other reasons to go to A&E include heavy bleeding, difficulty breathing, chest pain, or if you are unable to get to A&E, you can call 999.

a: Complications of a broken collarbone are rare but can include chest pain, difficulty breathing, and coughing up blood.

a: If you're unable to get to A&E, you should call 999 for emergency assistance.
